About/Philosophy.title: Philosophy
About/Philosophy.content:
This vault is designed to be as bare bones as possible, and to look as good as possible in default obsidian (dark mode)‚Ä¶ However:

A theme is recommended for the best/most aesthetic experience

Our note taking methods rely heavily on callouts, which the default obsidian theme clashes badly with
If you aren‚Äôt sure about what theme to pick, I recommend AnuPpucin




We have a relative naming system:


Please categorize any note/file in the correct subject folder (i.e. English)


Name any sub-folders within said subject folders with the corresponding course code (i.e. ENG2D1)

Name any notes within those sub-folders with a clear definition of the note (i.e. Quotes 2-3)



Keep all files within the corresponding file folder (i.e. MCR3U5 - Images)

Name any files within those folders using the format ‚ÄúFigure [num].[num]‚Äù

Math/MCR3U5/MCR3U5---Unit-6.title: MCR3U5 - Unit 6
Math/MCR3U5/MCR3U5---Unit-6.content:
L1: Periodic Functions
Notes


                  
                  What is a periodic function? 
                  
                
A periodic function is a function in which the values of y repeat at regular intervals of Œ∏.


                  
                   
                  
                
The height of somebody who is taking a ride on a large Ferris wheel is periodic.




[!blank-container]

[!blank-container|float-right]


The primary trigonometric ratios
(y=sinŒ∏, y=cosŒ∏, y=tanŒ∏) are periodic functions.



                  
                  Vocabulary for periodic functions 
                  
                

Cycle:
A complete series of y values (peak to peak/trough to trough)


Period:
The horizontal distance between the beginning of the cycle and the end


Amplitude:
Vertical distance between the middle of the graph and the peak/trough of the function


Midline:
Horizontal line that passes through the middle of the graph


Phase shift:
Horizontal translation of graph

[!blank-container|float-left]




Questions

Determine if the following functions are periodic. If they are, underline a cycle, trace the mid line, and indicate the period and amplitude of the function


[!blank-container]

[!blank-container|float-left]




                  
                  Answer 
                  
                
Periodic.
Midline: y=6
Period = 4
Amplitude = 4




[!blank-container]

[!blank-container|float-left]




                  
                  Answer 
                  
                
Not periodic.



[!blank-container]

[!blank-container|float-left]




                  
                  Answer 
                  
                
Periodic.
Midline: y=0
Period = 4
Amplitude = 4



L2: Transformations of Sin and Cos
Notes
$$\LARGE{y=af[k(x-d)]+c}$


                  
                  Transformations of \sin and \cos
                  
                

a has an affect on:

amplitude
max/min
range



k has an effect on:

periods
x-axis



d has an effect on:

phase shift
x-axis



c has an effect on:

peak/trough
range
y-axis





                  
                  Key Formulas 
                  
                

amplitude¬†=2max‚àímin‚Äã


period¬†=‚à£k‚à£360¬∞‚Äã or ‚à£k‚à£2œÄ‚Äã


midline:
y=c
or
c=2max+min‚Äã


phase shift:
(x+45¬∞) when d=‚àí45¬∞
(x‚àí45¬∞) when d=45¬∞

Info
                  
                

Switch between light and dark mode to see the difference.
Switch between reading and preview mode to see the difference.
I am using quick latex plugin for quickly wiriting the formulaes.
You can also use the desmos plugin to create desmos graph in your notes.
For the inverting image check the invert image css in the snippets folder and modify it if it is not working properly for you.


Notes
1. Distance Formulae

[!blank-container]

[!blank-container|float-right]


The distance between two points P(x1‚Äã,y1‚Äã) and Q(x2‚Äã,y2‚Äã) is given by PQ=(PR)2+(QR)2‚Äã=(x2‚Äã‚àíx1‚Äã)2+(y2‚Äã‚àíy1‚Äã)2‚Äã


                  
                  Remark M(x_{0},y_{0}) from origin O(0,0) OM=\sqrt{(x_{0}^{2}+y_{0}^{2})}
